text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the lobby and leaves for work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up the stairs to his apartment on the 10th floor.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out why this man takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor on rainy days.
Let me start by breaking down the problem step by step.
First, the man lives on the 10th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the lobby, which is the ground floor, probably the 1st floor.
Then he leaves for work.
In the evening, he returns and takes the elevator to the 7th floor.
From there, he walks up the stairs to his apartment on the 10th floor.
So normally, when it's not raining, he takes the elevator down in the morning and up to the 7th floor in the evening, then walks up from there.
But on rainy days, he changes his routine.
Instead of getting off at the 7th floor, he stays on the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.
That seems a bit odd because why would he go all the way up on a rainy day when he's usually trying to avoid stairs? Maybe there's something about the weather that makes this change necessary.
I'm thinking about the possible reasons.
One thought is that maybe the elevator isn't working properly on rainy days.
If the elevator is malfunctioning, he might have to take the stairs, which he doesn't want to do because it's raining.
So, taking the elevator all the way would be a way to avoid getting wet or dealing with a broken elevator.
Another possibility is that the man is trying to save time.
If the elevator is faster, especially when he's in a hurry, maybe on rainy days he prefers not to walk up the stairs because it takes longer.
But wait, he usually takes the elevator down in the morning, so time might not be the main issue here.
Wait, maybe it's about the building's design or the elevator's range.
If the elevator can only go up to the 7th floor normally, perhaps on rainy days, the elevator's maximum height is increased or it's being serviced, allowing him to go all the way to the 10th floor.
But that seems a bit far-fetched.
Alternatively, perhaps on rainy days, the man prefers to stay dry as much as possible.
By taking the elevator all the way up, he avoids walking up the stairs, which are likely wet from the rain.
That makes sense because walking up wet stairs could be slippery and uncomfortable.
I'm also considering the possibility of the stairs being out of service or under repair on rainy days.
If the stairs are closed, he might have no choice but to take the elevator all the way.
But the problem doesn't mention anything about the stairs being unavailable, so maybe it's more about his preference for staying dry.
So, putting it all together, the most plausible reason is that on rainy days, he wants to avoid walking up the wet stairs, so he takes the elevator all the way to his apartment to stay dry.

</think>

The man takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor on rainy days to avoid walking up the wet and potentially slippery stairs.
This ensures he stays dry and avoids discomfort.
